data.author: Scott Elder

data.text: just my 2 cents but if you did it once you can do it again. I broke my patella last Halloween and have been through 2 knee surgeries since then. I ride my bike everywhere. I clip in the left leg and go. Trust and believe there have been days when I have wanted to give up and call for a ride home but I just don't have any quit left in me. My left leg is huge and my right leg is tiny but I just don't quit. If I can do it then you can do it.

data.text: thank you for the encouragement
data.author: MarkSteve Carreon

data.text: the cycling community is a big awesome family. A lot of people have helped encourage me along the way. Trust me ride that Marin up that hill until it is easy. Then you will be glad you didn't buy the ebike and you can take all the money you saved and buy yourself and awesome bike. Plus everyone at the gym will be jealous of your legs!!!

data.author: MarkSteve Carreon

data.text: Sounds like you want an electric Gravel bike. Yamaha and Cannondale have more affordable options than Trek or Specialized. I don't prescribe to the eBike hate. Most of the haters have never ridden one. Pedal assist eBikes still take effort and still give you good exercise. For the majority of couch to biking folks, an eBike is shown to be better than a standard bike. eBikes will be used more often and longer stretches of time because they don't produce the same type of post exercise pain. Additionally some people have health issues where a regular bike would be unrealistic. I myself have both regular and eBike available for this very reason. When I started biking again an eBike made it possible. After about a year of eBiking I was able to get a regular bike as well. Some days though, I'm really really glad I've still got the eBike as an option. Reply with your approximate budget and what distances you plan to ride regularly and I'd be happy to throw out some specific models that might work well. Edit. Oh and do you prefer flat bars? Or drop bars? Either are definitely good for adventure and bikepacking. Drop bars are the traditional/trendy way to do gravel. Drops give you more options for hand/body position, very helpful on long rides. You also tend to be in a more aerodynamic position with helps anytime you are going over about 15mph. Flat bars are oftentimes seen as simple and more familiar (And oftentimes cheaper).
data.author: Christopher Burkhart

data.text: this is Exactly was in my mind when I post this message I plan on using it for some real Adventure, maybe 1 to 3 days ride probably 300km or more. Adding more load to the bike will be hard for a regular bike but with a pedal assist might work for those distance! The current bike that I have will be my recreational bike down hill etc. The Pedal Assist will be more of a Adventure Longer ride using all kinds of terrain Gravel, Rocky, Muddy etc. I prefer a Flat Bar thats where I am comfortable at.
data.author: MarkSteve Carreon

data.text: I'm assuming you'll be stopping overnight at places where you can recharge. Because, unfortunately, 300km wouldn't be achievable in a single charge, even with some of the double battery bikes or bringing a 2nd battery along. Additionally, IMHO, you'll need an efficient mid-drive eBike for those distances and terrain.. You'll want to be looking at bikes like a Yamaha Torc or the new Ride1Up Prodigy XC for affordable options in this category. Mid-drive will only give you power as you need it thanks to built-in torque sensors detecting the amount of effort you are putting in... Then allowing the motor to assist with an additional % of power up to your defined limit. Cheaper hub motor setups use cadence sensors... If your legs are spinning, even freely without resistance, it's dumping in the maximum power the current level allows. Giving you the boost and draining power regardless of your need. Can add a few more options and pros/cons later if needed.
data.author: Christopher Burkhart
MarkSteve Carreon

data.text: I had success with a bafang mid drive conversion for my father, at 74 I can't fault him for wanting a little assistance. Easy install and easy return to non powered.
